title: Use of OWL and Semantic Web Technologies at Pinterest

author: Rafael Gonçalves, Stanford Center for Biomedical Informatics Research

segmentation: I'm rough Elvis Elvis from Stanford University.
I'll be presenting a joint work between the project team at Stanford and the content management team at Pinterest.

Throughout the next 15 minutes or so, I'm going to be pretty much demonstrating to you that the combination of a little semantics and the right tooling can go a long way, and that's pretty much the moral of this story.
Now what is Pinterest?
Pinterest is a visual exploration platform.
It allows people to look for things that they like.
This might be places that they would like to visit, like Tropical Islands.
It might be things that they would like to do like scuba diving, or it could be things that they like to wear like leather jackets or bohemian dresses.
Now the home feeds over user on Pinterest displays the pins that a user has pinned.
In other words has bookmarked and also displays pins that are recommended to the user.
Based on this user's engagement with other pins.
Pinterest platform contains.
This is not working.
Contains 250 million users.
There also known as Pinners.
I did not make this up and overall the platform contain.
It's just over 175 billion pins.
Now a pin is.
Basically a image.
It contains some representation of a place or a piece of clothing or whatever.
In this case we've got the Elrod House that was designed by John Lautner.
It contains some title that briefly describes this pin and contains an information about the Pinner himself or herself, and link to an external website and the description of this pin.
Now, interest decided to define a set of terms interests.
They call it and these interests are sometimes keywords that were extracted from the text of pins.
They could also be terms that were used in popular queries on Pinterest.
Now these interests are used by Pinterest for precise ad targeting as well As for recommending pins, and they do so by labeling the pins and pinners with these interests.

One thing to note is that pinners do not themselves annotate their own pins with these interests, so it's a bit of a challenge to get the any kind of analysis done of their tastes or interests, as well as the as well as the target ads to them.
So in this figure.
I'm showing you a broad overall picture of the Pinterest spacecraft.
It's what they call their knowledge graph on the right hand side.
We've got this interest ontology.
This is what I'll be talking to you about, primarily in the next few minutes, and they combine that with some information about the Pinner and as well as about the pin.
So in this case we've got a Pinner that's safe sump into his own board.
This is the Elrod House again, and this pin depicts an interest in mid century architecture.
Here so here we are in the interest taxonomy and so we get that the spinner is also interested in mid century architecture.
Now who might be interested in this?
Well, advertisers who are trying to sell for example, furniture that has been styled in this new century architecture.
They'd be interested in targeting these users.
The initial Pinterest taxonomy had about 6000 interests.
They were organized into three level hierarchy.
This was all done in Excel in a spreadsheet, so obviously it was very difficult to visualize things.
It was hard to keep track of changes.
It was hard to tell who made what change and when.
It was also really hard to attach any kind of metadata to these interests.
So Pinterest decided to invest.
In improving their taxonomy.

I'm sorry and decided to move to a standard knowledge representation language such as owl that will allow him to be more flexible in their representation of the domain knowledge, and I wanted to move to a better tool that will allow them to collaborate and to discuss things to keep track of changes and so forth and so on.
So we appreciate to the rescue.
In this picture I'm showing you the default interface of Proto shape on the left hand side.
We've got the class hierarchy.
You'll notice that some entities have been tagged here with some colorful tags in the center.
We've got some information about the selected entity, such as relationships that it plays a part in on the right hand side on the top.

We've got some comments that have been done on this particular selected entity, and at the bottom right we've got a project feed that is updated in real time with changes that have happened across the project.
Now, in moving to using the Web Ontology language as their representation language and using Web protege as their collaboration tool, interest was able to build an intern system in just two months.
They've built a new version of their ontology as a apology, and this was this was built based on some 5000 new interests that were mined from user provided content.
Pinterest has built guidelines and workflows for human curators that are distributed across the globe.
And if essentially developed an entire pipeline that consumes this all autology and then populate some databases that are used for ad targeting an for recommending pins to other users.
Now.
Well, unfortunately I could really show you the Pinterest Ontology.
I can talk to you about some major modeling decisions that we've done, and this was a big one.
With this item model interest, as our classes and I'm giving you here an example of why that might be a bad idea.

So we've got a painter who is interested in San Francisco, and you might think there's only one San Francisco in our domain of discourse, the world, and so we think that SF should be modeled as an individual San Francisco de Place.
However, if you apply the same reasoning for this example, things get a little bit more complicated.
So here I'm interested in cute cats videos of cats, and I am, but I'm not interested in anyone particular video.
I'm interested just in general and kid videos of cats.

So in our taxonomy we're not modeling the things themselves were not modeling San Francisco, the place we're not modeling any specific videos of cats were modeling interests in those things, and that's an important distinction.
And by modeling these things as our classes.
We get the advantage that we can easily specialize them if we saw one to do.
And so by doing so, we can say, for example, that an interest in 1960s San Francisco is also an interest in San Francisco.

Now going back to the web browser user interface, I mentioned these tags on the left hand side also showing here the change history for this specific entity, which was one of the requirements by Pinterest.

We've designed this tags management mechanism that allows people to create tags that are composed of a label on the left hand side description and the color and each tag can basically be assigned in either manual way or automatically based on a live query that is done using.
This next user interface.

In here we can design any kind of not any kind, but some specific kinds of criterias that has support for, for example some complex, multiple, disjunctive and conjunctive criteria as well as paths with values and pass along values and.
Essentially we can design here constraints or or queries that are very close to a shackle core implementation.
In this particular example, we've got the criteria that we specify here.

For using the missing definition tag, is that it should be a descendant of an Airbus aircraft that does not have an annotation value for this cost definition, so these entities will be tagged with the missing definition tag, which is selected down under.
And these tags are also searchable so I can look up for any kind of any entities that have been tagged with a particular tag by just doing a plain search.
Now another thing that Pinterest really needed was to be able to have multiple languages displayed at the same time in the class hierarchy.
So by default position used to just display one language whatever is selected in the user interface.
But because there was a necessity to have two languages side by side, we've implemented this functionality which allows people to have two languages.
So we have a primary language on the left and the secondary language on the right.
In this case it's Hungarian and you'll notice that there are two entities that have been tagged with this H2 tag, which.
Was built as A tag to denote entities that are missing a label in Hungarian, specifically in the Hungarian language.
The developer.
Team of Pretty of Pinterest was fairly small.
They had eight curators.
None of them had any experience with our web protege protege or any of these tools they didn't know about the semantic web.
We had a one hour training session with them.
We taught him how to use repetition and they went off and they created a new ontology in under one month.
So they went from.
5000 axioms in their initial interest taxonomy into an ontology that contain 145 thousand axioms.
Out of those, 25,000 are logical axioms, and the rest will be annotation axioms.
They went from 6000 classes to 11,000 classes.
Again.
They've used a lot of the terms they've mined.
The terms that they had in the most popular queries on the platform, as well as the user provided content in the pins themselves.
Anyway, from A3 level hierarchy to a 12 level hierarchy at most.
Now the petition managed with pressure, allows you to manage an issue.
Comments which are sort of like issues that you can resolve or resolve, and you can discuss these things.
And this was a big deal for them because they did need to discuss a lot of these things and clarify a lot of these things while they were developing it.
So overall we had about 2000 comments spread across 1000 threads throughout the development of this initial version of the OWL Ontology.
Another thing that pinches wanted to do was keep track of changes across the evolution of the project, and so this was just a default functionality of Protege.

I'm showing here, just some a list of details that have happened in a toy ontology mean you can see specific revisions, what happened in them, who did what changes and when, and I can also revert these changes and download this particular efficient.
This were some of the requirements that Pinterest wanted.
So overall, the expressivity of the ontology is just under our two yell.

It's not overly complex, but in the next version of our taxonomy will want to support faceted based classification of interests so that we can, for example, classify interest by their color by their brand by the material that they were made from, and so forth and so on.
And to do that we plan to use existential restrictions along with defined classes.
So there will be a next iteration of our taxonomy.
Anne.
So to summarize, the development cycle of the.
Pinterest Taxonomy was drastically reduced right after they started to use repetition.
Yell format gives them a lot of flexibility with respect to the kinds of things that they can say.
I'll allow them to say precisely what they wanted to do, but also allows it for further extensions such as being able to clarify classify things by there.
Facets now another thing was that this led to a lot more engagement from teams that were not used to interacting with this particular kind of artifact.

It used to be that Pinterest employees would share the terminology across other teams, because obviously this involves the ads teams and their recommendation teams, but it was really difficult to get feedback from them.
They didn't know what to look for.
They had no idea what they were looking at in that spreadsheet.
Once they move to Web protege, giving them this nice user interface with the ability to comment and visualize and search for things easily.

They had a lot more engagement and this led to a lot more iterations of the ontology and they were able to flesh out the new ontology very quickly, taking into account feedback from those people who will be using that ontology downstream.

In other words, that people who are targeting ads and the people who are recommending pins so they were able to take this ontology and to populate their appropriate databases so that they can do those operations a lot better.

Another point was that the all representation has measurably increased the revenue of the company they engaged with advertisers a lot more advertisers gave really good feedback on the terminology and on the system that they've provided based on these ontology interests.
And in the end, we're hoping that having this this.

Facets of interest will allow us to create define classes such as white things or pink things or leather things, and this will allow people to do more and more effective searches will allow more precise ad targeting and again will create better recommendations.
Or users.
So hopefully I will have shown you that little semantics combined with some suitable tooling and appropriate tooling did go along way.
At least they did for us and we hope that these lessons are so much generalizable.
Thank you.
